Transcription for 19472

A Little Boy Lost from Songs of Experience by William Blake
Read by Dudley Sutton for the BBC
Nor loves another as itself, nor venerates another so,
Nor is it possible to thought a greater than itself to know.
And, Father, how can I love you or any of my brothers more?
I love you like the little bird that picks up crumbs around the door.
The priest sat by and heard the child. In trembling zeal he seized his hair.
He led him by his little coat and all admired the priestly care.
And standing on the altar high, lo, what a fiend is here, said he,
One who sets reason up for judge of our most holy mystery.
The weeping child could not be heard. The weeping parents wept in vain.
They stripped him to his little shirt and bound him in an iron chain,
And burned him in a holy place where many had been burned before.
The weeping parents wept in vain. Are such things done on Albion's shore?
